River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, but the crowning descision made by director Vincent Ward is the complete lack of subtitles for any of this movie's non-English dialogue. As a result, River Queen plays like an acid trip where you don't laugh at or freak out over what others are seeing; instead you watch "the best bits"

predictable, campy, bad special effects. it has a TV-movie feeling to it. the voices work nicely--there is a Brick and Mortar's tour of Hell sequence foreshadowing Hellboy: Blood & Iron (released in theatres in 2004), and the ending scenes of the movie featuring Abe and B.P.R.D. do not bode well for that Soul Storm comic

The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, they do not realize that what was going on with them is solely related to an unseen creature from thousands and thousands of years ago. Unfortunately for them, this creature wants to eat.
I give The Bone Snatcher 2 out of 5 Knuckle Bones.<|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|>

Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. But it’s got vibes that pulls you back again to watch it.
I was really happy to find this full length version of Snow White on YouTube and I adore Brother Bear’s new guitar tune “Yaaa boo !” No idea if that’s actually mentioned in the movie or not…
As far as television shows go

What is left of Planet Earth is populated by a few poor and starving rag-tag survivors. They must eat bugs and insects, or whatever they can find. The wealthy fliers have long since left Planet Earth, for adventures in the countless empires that make up the Galaxy beyond. Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an homage to both "Conan The Barbarian" and "Enter the Dragon." The film was directed by Fred Olen Ray, and it features Loni Anderson of Kathie Lee Gifford fame.<|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|>
